content.question: An antiderivative of <math alttext="the fraction with numerator sine x, and denominator 1 plus, cosine x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math> is <math alttext="the negative of the natural log of, open parenthesis, 1 plus, cosine x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following statements about the integral <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to pi, of, the fraction with numerator sine x, and denominator 1 plus, cosine x, end fraction, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is true?

choices.label: The integral equals <math alttext="2 over pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The integral equals <math alttext="the natural log of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>.

The integral diverges because <math alttext="the limit as x approaches pi from the left, of, the fraction with numerator sine x, and denominator 1 plus, cosine x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> does not exist.

The integral diverges because <math alttext="the limit as x approaches pi from the left, of, open parenthesis, the negative of the natural log of, open parenthesis, 1 plus, cosine x, close parenthesis, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> does not exist.
